discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
Agree with the answer

questions.question_text:
A retail company has 2000+ stores spread across the country. Store Managers report that they are having trouble running key reports related to inventory management, sales targets, payroll, and staffing during business hours. The Managers report that performance is poor and time-outs occur frequently.

Currently all reports share the same Snowflake virtual warehouse.

How should this situation be addressed? (Choose two.)

choices.D: Configure the virtual warehouse to size 4-XL.
choices.A: Use a Business Intelligence tool for in-memory computation to improve performance.
choices.C: Configure the virtual warehouse to be multi-clustered.
choices.B: Configure a dedicated virtual warehouse for the Store Manager team.
choices.E: Advise the Store Manager team to defer report execution to off-business hours.

questions.question_text:
A company needs to have the following features available in its Snowflake account:

1. Support for Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
2. A minimum of 2 months of Time Travel availability
3. Database replication in between different regions
4. Native support for JDBC and ODBC
5. Customer-managed encryption keys using Tri-Secret Secure
6. Support for Payment Card Industry Data Security Standards (PCI DSS)

In order to provide all the listed services, what is the MINIMUM Snowflake edition that should be selected during account creation?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Answer is C:
Customer-managed encryption keys through Tri-Secret Secure: Available in Business Critical and VPS
 Support for PCI DSS: Available in Business Critical and VPS
Secure data sharing across regions and cloud platforms (through data replication): NOT IN VPS and available in all other editions

questions.question_text: When using the COPY INTO [table] command with the CSV file format, how does the MATCH_BY_COLUMN_NAME parameter behave?

choices.D: The command will return a warning stating that the file has unmatched columns.
choices.A: It expects a header to be present in the CSV file, which is matched to a case-sensitive table column name.
choices.C: The command will return an error.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
CSV is now supported

Correct Answer: C
COPY INTO <table> Command: MATCH_BY_COLUMN_NAME Copy Option Returns Error w
when Loading CSV Data

When MATCH_BY_COLUMN_NAME is specified, Snowflake expects the first row of the CSV file to contain column headers.
Snowflake then matches these column headers (which are case-sensitive) with the column names in the target table.
The matching is done based on the order and names of the columns in the CSV file header and the target table. If a column in the CSV file header does not match any column in the target table, it may cause an error or a warning, depending on other parameters and settings.
Since option A isn't true unless the parameter is set to CASE_SENSITIVE and CSV column name detection is in Open Private Preview only , the correct answer here should be C

choices.E: Assign the ACCOUNTADMIN role to the user who is executing the object.
choices.D: Determine if there are OWNERSHIP privileges on the masking policy that would allow the use of any function.
choices.B: Set masking policy conditions using IS_ROLE_IN_SESSION targeting the role in use for the current account.
choices.C: Set masking policy conditions using INVOKER_ROLE targeting the executing role in a SQL statement.
choices.A: Set masking policy conditions using CURRENT_ROLE targeting the role in use for the current session.

questions.question_text: How can the Snowflake context functions be used to help determine whether a user is authorized to see data that has column-level security enforced? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
The following examples show how to use the INVOKER_ROLE in a masking policy SQL expression.
Return NULL for unauthorized users:
CREATE OR REPLACE MASKING POLICY mask_string AS
(val string) RETURNS string ->
CASE
 WHEN INVOKER_ROLE() IN ('ANALYST') THEN val
 ELSE NULL
END;

A: The CURRENT_ROLE() context function returns the role currently active for the session. Masking policies can be configured to apply based on the current role, allowing different views of data based on the user's role.
C: The INVOKER_ROLE() context function returns the role that invoked the function or SQL statement. This allows masking policies to dynamically apply based on the role executing the query, ensuring data security based on the user's permissions.
Which you then use to determine whether the column is visible in a data masking arrangement. Why can't B be used?

Changing to A & C. Although C isn't recommended, it is the more accurate description. For B the documentation states: Verifies whether the account role is in the user’s active primary or secondary role hierarchy for the session or if the specified column contains a role that is in the user’s active primary or secondary role hierarchy for the session.
